response: "{ \"title\": \"Easy: Counting Mountains\", \"description\": \"Given a list of integers representing elevations, write a function `count_mountains` that counts the number of mountains (i.e., elevations that are greater than their neighboring elevations). The input list will always have at least three elements.\\n\\n#### Function Signature\\n```python\\ndef count_mountains(elevations: list[int]) -> int:\\n```\\n\\n#### Input\\n- `elevations` (list[int]): A list of integers representing elevations, with at least three elements.\\n\\n#### Output\\n- Returns the number of mountains in the input list.\", \"code\": \"def count_mountains(elevations: list[int]) -> int:\\n    count = 0\\n    for i in range(1, len(elevations) - 1):\\n        if elevations[i] > elevations[i-1] and elevations[i] > elevations[i+1]:\\n            count += 1\\n    return count\", \"tests\": [\"assert count_mountains([1, 2, 3]) == 0\", \"assert count_mountains([1, 5, 4, 7, 6, 8]) == 2\", \"assert count_mountains([10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15]) == 0\"] }"
